This implies the centers of the small circles form a regular hexagon with side length 6.

The distance between the center of the large circle and the center of a small circle is given by the side length of the hexagon, which is 6.  The radius of the large circle, $r$, and the side length of the hexagon, 6, form a right triangle.  The distance from the center of the large circle to the center of one of the small circles forms a 30-60-90 triangle with the radius of the large circle. The distance between the center of the large circle and one of the small circles is $\sqrt{3} \times 3 = 3\sqrt{3}$. The radius of the large circle is $3+r$.

Using the 30-60-90 triangle, we have $r^2 + 3^2 = (3+r)^2$. This simplifies to $r^2 + 9 = (3+r)^2 = r^2 + 6r + 9$, which gives $0 = 6r$, so $r=0$. This is incorrect.
The distance from the center of the large circle to the center of a small circle is the radius of the large circle plus the radius of a small circle, which is $r+3$. The distance from the center of the large circle to the center of a small circle is also the distance from the center of a small circle to the center of an adjacent small circle, which is 6. Thus $r+3 = 3 \sqrt{3}$. So $r = 3 \sqrt{3} - 3 = 3 (\sqrt{3} - 1)$.
The diameter is $2r = 2(3\sqrt{3} - 3) = 6\sqrt{3}-6$. $2r = 6 \sqrt{3} - 6$.
The diameter is $2r = 2 \times 3 \sqrt{3} = 6 \sqrt{3}$.  The radius is $3 \sqrt{3}$.
$3(\sqrt{3} - 1)$.  The radius is $3 \sqrt{3} - 3 = 3(\sqrt{3}-1)$.  $2r = 6(\sqrt{3}-1)$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{6 \sqrt{3}}$
